content: The 114th Congress is focused on supporting federal R&D activities despite concerns about the federal debt. The government plays a crucial role in funding R&D efforts that have led to scientific advancements and new technologies. Prioritization of R&D is challenging due to budget deficits and competing needs within the federal R&D portfolio. The U.S. government supports a wide range of scientific and engineering R&D for national defense, health, safety, environment, and energy security. The federal R&D budget is an aggregation of the R&D components of each federal agency, developed internally as part of each agency's budget process and approved by the Office of Management and Budget. The federal R&D budget is determined by aggregating the R&D components of each federal agency, with Congress playing a key role in setting priorities and funding levels. Concerns have been raised about federal spending given the current deficit and debt. Congress faces challenges in growing R&D investments amidst budget constraints and must prioritize and allocate available funding. Budget caps may limit overall R&D funding, requiring resource reallocation across disciplines, programs, or agencies. The report discusses the complexity of funding for programs/agencies, starting with the President's FY2016 R&D request and analyzing it from various perspectives. It also includes the R&D budget requests of federal departments and agencies, accounting for over 98% of total federal R&D funding. President Obama's proposed FY2016 budget was released on February 2, 2015. The President's FY2016 budget proposes $145.694 billion for R&D, a 5.5% increase from FY2015. This includes a real increase of 3.9% after adjusting for inflation. Congress and Presidents Bush and Obama aimed to double funding for physical science and engineering research in the first four years of Obama's presidency. The R&D emphasis in disciplines like DOE Office of Science, NSF, and DOC NIST core laboratory research aimed to double funding as per President Bush's American Competitiveness Initiative and budget requests from President Obama. However, appropriations fell short of authorized levels in relevant acts. In FY2015, the President requested a 1.2% increase in funding for targeted accounts. In his FY2016 budget, President Obama is requesting a 5.7% increase in funding for targeted accounts, aiming to double the funding in about 12 years. Obama's goal is to increase national investment in R&D to over 3% of the U.S. GDP, without specifying the means to achieve this. In 2012, R&D as a percentage of GDP was 2.89%, with federal government contributing 0.86% and non-federal sources contributing 2.02%. Achieving the 3% goal would require a substantial increase in government and corporate R&D spending, estimated at $18 billion above the actual U.S. R&D funding level of $452.6 billion. Analysis of federal R&D funding is complicated by inconsistencies among agencies in reporting R&D activities. Federal R&D funding can be analyzed from various perspectives, including by agency, type of work supported, and whether it is defense-related. President Obama's FY2016 budget request allocated over 95% of total federal R&D funding to seven agencies, with the Department of Defense receiving the largest share. Congress makes funding decisions through the authorization and appropriations process primarily based on individual agencies and programs. The report analyzes R&D budget requests for key federal agencies, including NIH, DOE, NASA, NSF, USDA, and DOC. These agencies, along with others like DHS and EPA, account for over 98% of federal R&D funding. The largest increases in R&D funding in the President's FY2016 request are for DOD, DOE, DOC, HHS, USDA, and NSF. In President Obama's FY2016 budget request, federal R&D funding for various agencies would see changes, with some agencies receiving increases while others facing decreases. The budget includes allocations for basic research, applied research, development, and facilities/equipment. The rationale for public investments in basic research is based on the belief that the private sector may underinvest in this area without government support. The federal government funds the majority of basic research in the US, as private companies often underinvest in this area due to factors like long time horizons, technical risk, and shareholder demands for short-term returns. Industry primarily funds applied research instead. In the United States, industry is the main funder of applied research, accounting for 54.0% in 2012, while the federal government funded 36.2%. Industry also provides the majority of funding for development, contributing 76.4% in 2012, compared to the federal government's 22.1%. Federal R&D funding reflects national priorities such as spaceflight, energy sources, and counterterrorism efforts. In the President's FY2016 budget request, the Department of Health and Human Services, primarily NIH, would account for nearly half (48.8%) of all federal funding for basic research and about 43.5% of all federally funded applied research. DOD is the primary federal funder of development, accounting for 85.6% of total federal development funding. Defense-related R&D is mainly provided by the Department of Defense, fluctuating between 50% and 70% of total federal R&D funding. Defense-related R&D funding has fluctuated between 50% and 70% of total federal R&D funding for over three decades. In FY2016, the President's budget allocated $76.9 billion for defense-related R&D (52.8% of total R&D request) and $68.8 billion for non-defense R&D (47.2% of total R&D request). The America COMPETES Act authorized increases for NSF, DOE, and NIST accounts, but funding fell below targets in subsequent years. Congress has not authorized appropriations for the targeted accounts beyond FY2013. FY2013 funding for the targeted accounts was $2.964 billion less than authorized, setting a pace to double over more than 22 years from the FY2006 level. Budget constraints have put the future of the doubling path in question. President Obama's budget plans aimed to double funding for basic research in targeted accounts over a specified period. While the FY2013 budget reiterated this goal without specifying a timeline, the FY2014 budget showed a commitment to increasing funding without doubling. The Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) was announced in June 2011 by President Obama to accelerate the discovery, manufacture, and deployment of advanced materials. Agencies are working on implementation strategies focused on creating an innovation infrastructure, achieving national goals with advanced materials, and preparing the next generation materials workforce. The initiative aims to speed up the understanding of materials science to provide practical information for American entrepreneurs and innovators to develop new products and processes. The White House asserts that American entrepreneurs and innovators will be able to use research from the Materials Genome Initiative to develop new products and processes, similar to how the Human Genome Project accelerated biological sciences. This research may lead to the identification of substitutes for critical minerals, the development of materials to reduce traumatic brain injuries, and the creation of new lightweight materials for vehicles. The FAA's R&D funding for FY2016 was $137.2 million above the FY2015 enacted level and $27.3 million below the requested level. P.L. 114-113 provided increased funding for National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) R&D and R&D facilities, but decreased funding for Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) R&D and R&D facilities.
